snippet.textDisplay:
As you rightly point out in the video, it's possible to hide colour banding by dithering. The simplest way to do this is to composite feint white noise over the top of the image.
It would be quite easy for MPEG decoders to composite white noise over the final image after decoding, and the result would look a lot better. I'm not really sure why every decoder doesn't already do this.
snippet.textOriginal:
As you rightly point out in the video, it's possible to hide colour banding by dithering. The simplest way to do this is to composite feint white noise over the top of the image.
It would be quite easy for MPEG decoders to composite white noise over the final image after decoding, and the result would look a lot better. I'm not really sure why every decoder doesn't already do this.

snippet.textDisplay:
Another thing - almost none of the videos you're watching today are really encoded in RGB colorspace, but in YUV, and that conversion can introduce further aliasing due to rounding errors. And yet another - some formats won't use the full 0-255 range, but rather limited 16-235, and then it can end up being stretched again to 0-255, essentially distancing the shades even more, introducing more banding, etc.


But the reasoning behind YUV format and its use (chroma subsampling) are quite interesting, also coming back to how humans perceive light with their eyes, I suggest reading up on it for anyone who isn't familiar.
snippet.textOriginal:
Another thing - almost none of the videos you're watching today are really encoded in RGB colorspace, but in YUV, and that conversion can introduce further aliasing due to rounding errors. And yet another - some formats won't use the full 0-255 range, but rather limited 16-235, and then it can end up being stretched again to 0-255, essentially distancing the shades even more, introducing more banding, etc.


But the reasoning behind YUV format and its use (chroma subsampling) are quite interesting, also coming back to how humans perceive light with their eyes, I suggest reading up on it for anyone who isn't familiar.

snippet.textDisplay:
The human eye is better at picking up dark than light, two bright values are more difficult to distinguish than two dark values.
For this reason, a lot of computers will store brightness values of pictures as square roots - there will be a lot more smaller numbers (darker pixels) than larger values (brighter pixels), just so we can feel more at peace when looking at it.
snippet.textOriginal:
The human eye is better at picking up dark than light, two bright values are more difficult to distinguish than two dark values. 
For this reason, a lot of computers will store brightness values of pictures as square roots - there will be a lot more smaller numbers (darker pixels) than larger values (brighter pixels), just so we can feel more at peace when looking at it.

snippet.textDisplay: Something I've always wondered after watching a lot of nature documentaries, especially with ocean episodes and whatnot, is that it seems like blues are especially hit hard.  Do most compression algorithms compress certain colors more than others?  I would guess blue could afford to be more compressed because it's generally the opposite of skin tones, which are often the focal subject and would benefit the most from a wider set of possible values.
snippet.textOriginal: Something I've always wondered after watching a lot of nature documentaries, especially with ocean episodes and whatnot, is that it seems like blues are especially hit hard.  Do most compression algorithms compress certain colors more than others?  I would guess blue could afford to be more compressed because it's generally the opposite of skin tones, which are often the focal subject and would benefit the most from a wider set of possible values.

snippet.textDisplay: What would be nice is if we did for video what the CD did for stereo audio. If only we had a cheap plastic disc that could be pressed super cheap, read by equipment that will fall in price over time and hold all the data required for near lossless or totally lossless compression. Back with audio we didn't really have any computing power that could in real time decompress compressed audio lossless or not but now we have computers fast enough to decompress either or both simultaneously. Ideally someone will invent and get to market some digital movie format that will be able to hold lossless video... though bluray quality is still fairly decent.
snippet.textOriginal: What would be nice is if we did for video what the CD did for stereo audio. If only we had a cheap plastic disc that could be pressed super cheap, read by equipment that will fall in price over time and hold all the data required for near lossless or totally lossless compression. Back with audio we didn't really have any computing power that could in real time decompress compressed audio lossless or not but now we have computers fast enough to decompress either or both simultaneously. Ideally someone will invent and get to market some digital movie format that will be able to hold lossless video... though bluray quality is still fairly decent.

snippet.textDisplay:
At the end of November 2018, Canadian Human Rights Attorney David Matas visited Israel for the second time last year to lecture at the UNESCO 13th World Conference on Bioethics, Medical Ethics and Health Law in Jerusalem.

Mr. Matas lectured on the ethical aspects of a long and comprehensive investigation of the issue of forced organ harvesting in China, which is being carried out by the ruling regime itself. The main victims of this practice are Falun Gong (also called Falun Dafa) practitioners. Falun Gong is a traditional spiritual discipline that abides by the principles of Truthfulness-Compassion-Forbearance and has been persecuted by the Chinese regime since 1999.

During his nine-day stay in Israel, Matas met with medical professionals, Knesset (Israeli Parliament) members, and legal experts. In particular, Matas raised the need for proactive measures to prevent people from unknowingly cooperating with this crime, the extensiveness of which was documented in a study conducted by Matas, former Canadian Secretary of State (Asia-Pacific) David Kilgour and investigative journalist Ethan Gutmann.

Meeting with Senior Judges
During his visit to Israel, Mr. Matas met with the chairman of the Israeli National Council for Bioethics, who is also the chairman of the Helsinki Committee in Israel. The chairman was already familiar with the issue of organ harvesting in China but wanted to learn more, especially since Israel is currently discussing new laws regarding medical ethics.

Another meeting was held with a retired senior judge who expressed his sympathy and support.

Screening of the Film “Hard to Believe” Followed by Panel Discussion at the Tel Aviv Cinematheque
On December 3, a diverse audience, mainly from the fields of medicine and law, was invited to listen to a panel of experts after a screening of the film “Hard to Believe.” The film is a documentary that examines the issue of forced live organ harvesting from prisoners of conscience in China. The panel's participants included Mr. Matas, the Director of the Sheba Heart Transplantation Unit Professor Jacob Lavee, and representative of the Israeli Falun Dafa Information Center Dr. Israela Yablonka.
snippet.textOriginal:
At the end of November 2018, Canadian Human Rights Attorney David Matas visited Israel for the second time last year to lecture at the UNESCO 13th World Conference on Bioethics, Medical Ethics and Health Law in Jerusalem.

Mr. Matas lectured on the ethical aspects of a long and comprehensive investigation of the issue of forced organ harvesting in China, which is being carried out by the ruling regime itself. The main victims of this practice are Falun Gong (also called Falun Dafa) practitioners. Falun Gong is a traditional spiritual discipline that abides by the principles of Truthfulness-Compassion-Forbearance and has been persecuted by the Chinese regime since 1999.

During his nine-day stay in Israel, Matas met with medical professionals, Knesset (Israeli Parliament) members, and legal experts. In particular, Matas raised the need for proactive measures to prevent people from unknowingly cooperating with this crime, the extensiveness of which was documented in a study conducted by Matas, former Canadian Secretary of State (Asia-Pacific) David Kilgour and investigative journalist Ethan Gutmann.

Meeting with Senior Judges
During his visit to Israel, Mr. Matas met with the chairman of the Israeli National Council for Bioethics, who is also the chairman of the Helsinki Committee in Israel. The chairman was already familiar with the issue of organ harvesting in China but wanted to learn more, especially since Israel is currently discussing new laws regarding medical ethics.

Another meeting was held with a retired senior judge who expressed his sympathy and support.

Screening of the Film “Hard to Believe” Followed by Panel Discussion at the Tel Aviv Cinematheque
On December 3, a diverse audience, mainly from the fields of medicine and law, was invited to listen to a panel of experts after a screening of the film “Hard to Believe.” The film is a documentary that examines the issue of forced live organ harvesting from prisoners of conscience in China. The panel's participants included Mr. Matas, the Director of the Sheba Heart Transplantation Unit Professor Jacob Lavee, and representative of the Israeli Falun Dafa Information Center Dr. Israela Yablonka.

snippet.textDisplay:
human vision being sensitive to relative rather than absolute differences in brightness is one of the reasons why Gamma Curve is a thing (the other being that old picture tubes had a non-linear response), so significantly more of the possible brightness values are allocated to the darker values rather than the brighter ones. unfortunately, they're not quite lined up.


the ideal gamma value to correspond to human vision is actually quite strong, about 3. old style picture tubes had a native gamma of about 2.4-2.5, so for the sake of cost, content was mastered to have the proper response curve on those old tubes, because it was close enough... and from the perspective of human vision, it absolutely was


part of the problem is that for whatever reason, for flatscreen displays, they decided to standardize the gamma curve at 2.2, rather weaker than the 2.5 of the old tube monitors, and significantly weaker than the ideal response curve for human vision. as such, banding in the dark parts of the image is significantly more noticeable than it used to be. and you can't really do anything about it either, since all modern content is mastered with the intention of being displayed on these 2.2 gamma displays, so even if your display has an option to change the gamma value, tweaking that will just make everything look wrong.
snippet.textOriginal:
human vision being sensitive to relative rather than absolute differences in brightness is one of the reasons why Gamma Curve is a thing (the other being that old picture tubes had a non-linear response), so significantly more of the possible brightness values are allocated to the darker values rather than the brighter ones. unfortunately, they're not quite lined up.


the ideal gamma value to correspond to human vision is actually quite strong, about 3. old style picture tubes had a native gamma of about 2.4-2.5, so for the sake of cost, content was mastered to have the proper response curve on those old tubes, because it was close enough... and from the perspective of human vision, it absolutely was


part of the problem is that for whatever reason, for flatscreen displays, they decided to standardize the gamma curve at 2.2, rather weaker than the 2.5 of the old tube monitors, and significantly weaker than the ideal response curve for human vision. as such, banding in the dark parts of the image is significantly more noticeable than it used to be. and you can't really do anything about it either, since all modern content is mastered with the intention of being displayed on these 2.2 gamma displays, so even if your display has an option to change the gamma value, tweaking that will just make everything look wrong.

snippet.textDisplay:
There's nothing inherently preventing post-decompression dithering, it's just a hard problem. But solving hard problems is one of those things people will pay for, so this too is likely to pass.


In the interim, you can get some relief on the input side by ETTR (exposing to the right) to get more image data into the dark areas at the cost of some data in the highlights.


For that matter, shifting the video to the right on the exposure, compressing, transmitting, decompressing, and shifting back to the left could be done right now without any special techniques.
snippet.textOriginal:
There's nothing inherently preventing post-decompression dithering, it's just a hard problem. But solving hard problems is one of those things people will pay for, so this too is likely to pass.


In the interim, you can get some relief on the input side by ETTR (exposing to the right) to get more image data into the dark areas at the cost of some data in the highlights.


For that matter, shifting the video to the right on the exposure, compressing, transmitting, decompressing, and shifting back to the left could be done right now without any special techniques.

snippet.textDisplay:
Some day in the future, we will likely see a 10 or 12 bit color standard become more prevalent.
It would consume a bit more bandwidth, but it would noticeable reduce color banding, and also offer better sharpness in an image.
Without the need to push for the far more bandwidth intensive resolution needed to achieve the same result with dithering.

Though, in some cases, color isn't described with absolute values to begin with, but rather using chromaticity, lightness and contrast. Though, that doesn't fix the issue with darkness, since the steps in lightness would still be there and just as obvious as ever....
snippet.textOriginal:
Some day in the future, we will likely see a 10 or 12 bit color standard become more prevalent.
It would consume a bit more bandwidth, but it would noticeable reduce color banding, and also offer better sharpness in an image.
Without the need to push for the far more bandwidth intensive resolution needed to achieve the same result with dithering.

Though, in some cases, color isn't described with absolute values to begin with, but rather using chromaticity, lightness and contrast. Though, that doesn't fix the issue with darkness, since the steps in lightness would still be there and just as obvious as ever....

snippet.textDisplay: Once a cinematographer colleague with some technical and colour theory background told me that the colour downsampling in modern HD codecs is so extreme that, in essence, the old DigiBeta format had more actual colour information per one PAL resolution frame than a compressed HD resolution frame.
snippet.textOriginal: Once a cinematographer colleague with some technical and colour theory background told me that the colour downsampling in modern HD codecs is so extreme that, in essence, the old DigiBeta format had more actual colour information per one PAL resolution frame than a compressed HD resolution frame.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm curious then, what are the drawbacks of moving the computation of dithering itself on the video player? Does that end up being potentially CPU/GPU intensive in some cases, and that the prevalence of youtube on many different device-performance-levels implies that this would be more difficult to implement? Would this then potentially be solved with a toggle in youtube as another video-quality toggle, much like how we can manually adjust the resolution? Or would it just be too much effort for a relatively low audience/use-case?
snippet.textOriginal: I'm curious then, what are the drawbacks of moving the computation of dithering itself on the video player? Does that end up being potentially CPU/GPU intensive in some cases, and that the prevalence of youtube on many different device-performance-levels implies that this would be more difficult to implement? Would this then potentially be solved with a toggle in youtube as another video-quality toggle, much like how we can manually adjust the resolution? Or would it just be too much effort for a relatively low audience/use-case?

snippet.textDisplay: So , the moral of the story is. . Not only can they control what we see just by controlling the compression,  they can control how good we see it .. they will slowly turn down the compression,  thus turning up the resolution on the UFO videos we see that are actually real stuff ...incidentally,  THIS is just 3% of what is being done in the whole "slow disclosure" that's been going on for decades now .
